Body:
One example of a non-argument of-phrase would be of-possessives. (Possessors are by definition not arguments.) The best way to make sure that an of phrase is really a possessive is to mark it (redundantly) with 's:

(1) That dog of John's is really vicious.

It is less than clear, syntactically/semantically speaking, what is going on here (Why the double-marking of possessive? Is there some kind of partitivity? What, if any, is the difference in meaning between the above and "John's dog"?) â€“ but it is clear that this is a non-argument of-phrase.

LastEditedUser.AboutMe: I am a second-year PhD student in Linguistics at the University of Pennsylvania. My research interests lie in diachronic syntax, language as an evolutionary system, and quantitative methods in linguistic research.
